concept.title: Landing gear
concept.shortdesc: The has retractable, tricycle landing gear, hydraulically operated.

conbody.p: The landing gear retracts aft, the main gear into the engine nacelles, the nose gear into the fuselage. Doors cover the gear openings in both the retracted and extended positions.

fig.title: Landing wheels retracting as the takes off
fig.desc: Image of an airplane taking off with its three wheels retracting into its fuselage and wings.

conbody.p: The landing gear control handle is on the lower section of the pilot's control pedestal. Three distinct safety devices prevent accidental movement of the control handle:

ol.li: A latch on the pedestal that must be set in the correct position before you can move the handle.

A wire hook fastened to the pedestal which is placed over the control handle whenever the handle is in the ''DOWN'' position. Landing gear mechanism locked in place when handle is in the "DOWN" position Image focusing on a handle which is locked into place using a latch.
Latch on the landing gear mechanism when it is in the "DOWN" position.

A locking plate that the pilot attaches to the pedestal whenever he leaves the airplane. Locking plate for landing gear mechanism Image focusing on a metal band that prevents a handle from coming out of position.
Landing gear mechanism with locking plate in place.

conbody.p: The swivel-type nose gear strut incorporates a centering device. It functions when weight is removed from the nosewheel. There is a shimmy damper on the nosewheel strut to absorb the vibrations created in taxiing. The nosewheel may be released from the shimmy damper for towing purposes. A static ground wire is attached to the nosewheel.

There is a position indicator for the landing gear on the instrument panel. A warning horn, replaced on later models by a warning light, indicates whether landing gear is down and locked when throttles are retarded.

You can check the position of the main wheels visually from the cockpit. Check the position of the nosewheel visually by use of the drift meter or by removing the inspection plate from the floor in front of the copilot.
The landing gear has smooth-contour wheels and tires. The nose wheel tire has a dual-seal tube, but the main wheel tires use regular lube.
The main wheels have hydraulically operated, multiple-disc brakes. Varying pressures on the toe pedals produce braking action.
Conventional parking brakes permit setting the brakes in a locked position.
For emergency operation of landing gear and brakes, see Emergency Section.

fig.title: Instrument indicating that landing gear is up and locked, flaps up
fig.desc: An instrument image of an airplane with three symbols indicating the landing wheels are up and locked, and a flap indicator pointing to "UP".

image.alt: Landing gear is up and locked, flaps up.

fig.title: Instrument indicating that the landing gear is part down, flaps 15deg
fig.desc: An instrument image of an airplane with three symbols indicating the landing wheels are partially down, and a flap indicator pointing to 15 degrees.

image.alt: Landing gear is part down, flaps 15deg.

fig.title: Instrument indicating that the landing gear is down but not locked, flaps 15deg
fig.desc: An instrument image of an airplane with three symbols indicating the landing wheels are down but not locked, and a flap indicator pointing to 15 degrees.

image.alt: Landing wheels are down but not locked, and a flap indicator pointing to 15 degrees.

fig.title: Instrument indicating that the landing gear down and locked, flaps 45deg
fig.desc: An instrument image of an airplane with three symbols indicating the landing wheels are down and locked, and a flap indicator pointing to 45 degrees.

image.alt: Landing gear down and locked, flaps 45deg.
